awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: De Novo Protein Constructs for  Photosynthetic Energy Transduction
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Michael Therien and David Beratan of Duke University and William DeGrado of University of California-San Francisco are studying new approaches to design materials that direct, store, and release energy. Biology has developed numerous designs that carry out these functions; chemists, however, have yet to create energy harvesting, storage, and release systems from scratch that possess the sophistication of those seen in nature. Recent advances in protein design enable chemists to construct large molecules that capture and manage the flow of positive charges, negative charges, and energy. By designing protein-based materials that migrate and collect charges and energy, unique optical, electrical, and chemical functions will be realized. The experimental procedures used in this effort will (i) provide new tools to build proteins having innovative designed functions, and (ii) characterize the structures and energy storage and release functions of these proteins. This pursuit will allow graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to acquire specialized training in synthetic chemistry, protein design, protein biochemistry, modern computational methods, and techniques to monitor fast processes that move charge and energy. The protein design methods developed will be broadly applicable, and enable construction of new biologically inspired materials that carry out novel functions not seen in nature. Outreach activities of this project will introduce college and pre-college students to important new technologies, and teach skills important for future careers in science and engineering.

Biological energy transduction relies on protein-cofactor assemblies that possess physico-chemical functionality that far exceeds that realized to date through molecular and macromolecular design and synthesis. This research project will be undertaken to realize such complex functionality through “design from scratch” strategies that exploit de novo proteins that bind abiological cofactors, and in the process, elucidate fundamental design principles required for photosynthetic energy transduction, storage, and release. This project takes advantage of an integrated, multi-disciplinary approach to evolve peptide-cofactor complexes that possess sophisticated electro-optic functionality, encompassing cofactor design and synthesis, advanced computational methods that provide proteins that bind these cofactors in precise, organized spatial arrangements, protein expression and characterization, state-of-the-art pump-probe transient optical methods that characterize function and reaction dynamics, and high resolution protein structure determination. Information from this study is expected to elucidate fundamental principles required for photosynthetic energy transduction, and designed proteins that possess novel electro-optical function and transduce energy via innovative pathways.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, SAN FRANCISCO, THE

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this proposal was to uncover the ways that proteins control biological energy transduction by building such function from scratch. Redox proteins transduce energy by orchestrating the movement of electrons, holes, and protons using bound cofactors, redox-active amino acids, titratable sidechains, and buried water. Our aim was to create fully functional de novo proteins to dissect the mechanisms of biological energy transduction through both experiment and theory.  To do this, we design “de novo” proteins that are built entirely from scratch, rather than modification of naturally existing proteins. 

 

The design of functional proteins is a grand challenge, and we made a great deal of progress towards this objective, particularly in the design of proteins that bind to small molecules.  While the de novo design of proteins with predetermined folds, and proteins that bind peptides or other proteins has reached an advanced state, the design of proteins that bind small molecules has remained difficult.  Moreover, in our project we not only needed to bind small molecules with nM affinity; we also needed to consider the dynamics of the protein and associated water molecules to enable the systematic control of electron and proton movement.

 

To achieve our goals we developed methods to facilitate the design of nM binders of small molecules: one such innovation was COMBS, which we developed to design binding sites in mathematically generated backbones, using an element of protein structure called van der Waals (vdW).  This method allowed us to design proteins that bound small molecule drugs such as apixaban and rucaparib, strong photoacids, such as naphthalene diimide (NDI)-based photooxidants, and electron-deficient zinc porphyrin proteins that act as photoacids (upon excitation with light, the porphyrin ejects a proton.  We also designed membrane proteins that control H+ flow through dynamically fluctuating water wires.

 

We then sent these designed proteins to Michale Therien’s lab (a collaborator in this collaborative project) to conduct excited-state dynamics using ultrafast pump-probe spectroscopic method for cofactors capable of both intramolecular and intermolecular electron and proton transfer. Their ongoing studies are elucidating fundamental mechanisms that lay the groundwork for creation of next-generation bioinspired photosynthetic nanomaterials.

 


Last Modified: 02/14/2025
Modified by: William F DeGrado

To do this, we design de novo proteins that are built entirely from scratch, rather than modification of naturally existing proteins.

While the de novo design of proteins with predetermined folds, and proteins that bind peptides or other proteins has reached an advanced state, the design of proteins that bind small molecules has remained difficult. We then sent these designed proteins to Michale Theriens lab (a collaborator in this collaborative project) to conduct excited-state dynamics using ultrafast pump-probe spectroscopic method for cofactors capable of both intramolecular and intermolecular electron and proton transfer.
